awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Accurate Determination of Acoustic Wave Sources using Periodic Microstructured Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to exploit the dynamic behavior of microstructured periodic materials to accurately locate the sources of sound waves.  The traditional method of identifying source location is using phased array sensors whose precision is limited by the size of the sensor in comparison with the wavelength of acoustic waves. This research will aim to use the vibrational properties of periodic composites to improve determination of source location.   The principles developed will have direct application to radar and associated technologies in both defense and civil applications.  Through various outreach efforts, this research will help in broadening the participation of the public in the highly multi-disciplinary subject of waves and their control.

Level Repulsion (LR) zones are frequency regions where the state of a periodic microstructured material undergoes rapid change in response to minute changes in a controlling parameter, e.g. wave incidence angle. Therefore they may be utilized for precise measurement of their controlling parameter, for example, the bearing angle of an incident stress wave. The principal research objectives of this project are: (a) To determine the conditions under which phononic eigenvalues coalesce to give rise to LR zones and to exploit this to demonstrate that phononic crystals can act as extremely sensitive directional sensors near LR zones; (b) To establish the relationships between the sensitivity of localization and the topological properties of LR zones in order to create tuned/tunable LR zones through modulations in the geometry or material properties of the PC; and (c) To create lab-scale phononic crystals and demonstrate the existence of LR zones, followed by verification of precision and robustness of the developed source localization methods in noisy and multisource environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Micro-structured media such as mechanical metamaterials and phononic crystals (PCs) exhibit rich modal behaviors in their eigen-space. This work investigated the phenomena of exceptional points (EPs) in particular, which are complex singularities in the spectrum often accompanied with rapid changes in the modal response. The analytical properties of EPs (and their related level repulsion phenomena) are exploited and leveraged for developing new source localization methods. The developed localization concept consists of deploying a periodic array of phononic unit cells, whose equi-frequency band possesses special branch points including EPs and critical angles. Operating in the designed frequency, the scattering responses of such a micro-structured array demonstrates rapid changes when the incoming stress angle reaches the EPs and critical angles, thus providing sensitive angular behaviors. This project produced: 1) an analytical model for assessing the metamaterial modal behavior near the EP regions, including the eigen-frequency modes and PT symmetric frequency domain scattering responses; 2) a parameter retrieval method for deriving dynamic constitutive properties of periodic structures; and 3) a deep-learning approach that leverages the rich modal response behaviors of PCs for accurate detection of source angle of arrival in localization problems (e.g. sonar).

 

The research outcomes include the listed analytical models, algorithms, and computational results supporting the implementation of source localization algorithms with phononic crystals. The methods and results can be generalized for other micro-structured designs such as locally resonant metamaterials, which can potentially offer combined functionalities and broadened design space.

 

The broader impacts of the project include improving the accuracy of current localization algorithms and opening new technological opportunities based on the micro-structural designs. This project partially trained 2 PhD students, and 2 undergraduate students were involved with the research. Results have been disseminated in five peer-reviewed journal papers and at 4 conferences.
